ProjectDescr.Name: Borreliella burgdorferi B31
ProjectDescr.Title: Causes Lyme disease
ProjectDescr.Description: Borrelia burgdorferi strain B31. This is the type strain (ATCC 35210) for this organism and was derived by limited dilutional cloning from the original Lyme-disease tick isolate derived by A. Barbour.

StructuredCitation.Title: Cross-species hybridization of a Borrelia burgdorferi DNA array reveals infection- and culture-associated genes of the unsequenced genome of the relapsing fever agent Borrelia hermsii.

Author.Consortium: Department of Microbiology and Molecular Genetics, University of California Irvine, Irvine, CA 92697-4025, USA.

StructuredCitation.Title: Genomic sequence of a Lyme disease spirochaete, Borrelia burgdorferi.

Author.Consortium: Institute for Genomic Research, Rockville, Maryland 20850, USA.

StructuredCitation.Title: A bacterial genome in flux: the twelve linear and nine circular extrachromosomal DNAs in an infectious isolate of the Lyme disease spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi.

Author.Consortium: Division of Molecular Biology and Genetics, Department of Oncological Sciences, University of Utah Medical School, Salt Lake City, UT 84132, USA.

ProjectDescr.Name: Treponema denticola ATCC 35405
ProjectDescr.Title: Causes periodontal disease, gum inflamation
ProjectDescr.Description: Treponema denticola ATCC 35405. Treponema denticola ATCC 35405 was isolated from a human periodontal pocket and is the type strain of this organism.

StructuredCitation.Title: Comparison of the genome of the oral pathogen Treponema denticola with other spirochete genomes.

Journal.JournalTitle: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

Author.Consortium: The Institute for Genomic Research, 9712 Medical Center Drive, Rockville, MD 20850, USA.

ProjectDescr.Name: Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum str. Nichols
ProjectDescr.Title: Causative agent of syphilis
ProjectDescr.Description:
Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum. This organism is the causative agent of endemic and venereal syphilis. This sexual transmitted disease was first discovered in Europe at the end of the fifteenth century, however, the causative agent was not identified until 1905. At one time syphilis was the third most commonly reported communicable disease in the USA. Syphilis is characterized by multiple clinical stages and long periods of latent, asymptomatic infection. Although effective therapies have been available since the introduction of penicillin, syphilis remains a global health problem.

Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum strain Nichols. This strain was originally isolated in 1912 from a neurosyphilitic patient and is virulent.

StructuredCitation.Title: Complete genome sequence of Treponema pallidum, the syphilis spirochete.

Author.Consortium: Institute for Genomic Research, Rockville, MD 20850, USA. tpdb@tigr.org

Organism.OrganismName: Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum str. Nichols

ProjectDescr.Title: Causes infertility, infectious abortions, septicemia, meningitis
ProjectDescr.Description: Campylobacter fetus subsp. venerealis str. Azul-94. Field isolate obtained from an aborted Bos taurus (cow) fetus (Year: 1994, Place: Tandil, Argentina).

StructuredCitation.Title: Genomic analysis of Campylobacter fetus subspecies: identification of candidate virulence determinants and diagnostic assay targets.

ProjectDescr.Name: Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168 = ATCC 700819
ProjectDescr.Title: Leading cause of food poisoning (altered virulence strain)
ProjectDescr.Description: Campylobacter jejuni strain NCTC11168. This strain (originally 5636/77) was isolated from a diarrheic patient in 1977 and minimally passaged. This strain displays aberrant virulence phenotypes in animal models and tissue culture. Contains many homopolymeric tracts in the genome which result in hypervariable sequences in many genes having to do with cell surface structures. These sequences result in hypervarible antigenic diversity and immune evasion. Overall, the genome contains very few repetitive DNA sequences and very few coding regions arranged in operons. Pathogenicity factors include cytolethal-distending toxin, hemolysin-like toxins, and a type II secretion system.

StructuredCitation.Title: The genome sequence of the food-borne pathogen Campylobacter jejuni reveals hypervariable sequences.

Author.Consortium: The Sanger Centre, The Wellcome Trust Genome Campus, Hinxton, Cambridge, UK.

StructuredCitation.Title: Re-annotation and re-analysis of the Campylobacter jejuni NCTC11168 genome sequence.

Author.Consortium: Pathogen Molecular Department, London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, UK. Ozan.gundogdu@lshtm.ac.uk <Ozan.gundogdu@lshtm.ac.uk>

Organism.OrganismName: Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168 = ATCC 700819

ProjectDescr.Name: Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis SCHU S4
ProjectDescr.Title: Aquatic bacterium that cause tularemia
ProjectDescr.Description: Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis strain Schu S4. This subspecies is virulent in humans, and the strain is a clinical isolate that is also virulent in an animal model. Originally isolated from a human case of tularemia in 1951. Genome analysis indicates the presence of a large number of pseudogenes, many that disrupt important metabolic pathways, which is the reason for the exacting nutritional requirements of this organism. There is a duplicated pathogenicity island that has also been detected in strain LVS and mutations in the iglA, iglC, or pdpD genes affect the ability of the pathogen to survive in macrophages. The genome also contains genes for type IV pili production and capsular polysaccharide genes similar to those of Bacillus anthracis as well as numerous ABC transporters. There are a large number of insertion sequences including a mariner element, which is a transposon typically found in eukaryotes and is the first instance of this element to be found in a microbe, which may have acquired it during transit through one of the insect vectors.

StructuredCitation.Title: Preliminary analysis and annotation of the partial genome sequence of Francisella tularensis strain Schu 4.

Author.Consortium: Defence Evaluation and Research Agency, CBD Porton Down, Salisbury, Wilts, UK.

StructuredCitation.Title: The complete genome sequence of Francisella tularensis, the causative agent of tularemia.

Author.Consortium: Swedish Defence Research Agency, SE-901 82 Ume√•, Sweden.

Organism.OrganismName: Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis SCHU S4

ProjectDescr.Name: Pseudomonas fluorescens Pf0-1
ProjectDescr.Title: Microorganism of putrefaction
ProjectDescr.Description: Pseudomonas fluorescens strain Pf0-1. This strain was isolated from agricultural loam (sand, clay, and organic matter) soil in 1988 by Compeau et al. and is well adapted to soil environments.

StructuredCitation.Title: Genomic and genetic analyses of diversity and plant interactions of Pseudomonas fluorescens.

Author.Consortium: Department of Molecular Biology and Microbiology, Tufts University School of Medicine, Centre for Adaptation Genetics and Drug Resistance, Boston, MA 02111, USA. mark.silby@tufts.edu

ProjectDescr.Name: Ralstonia pseudosolanacearum GMI1000
ProjectDescr.Title: Soil-born pathogen that naturally infects plant roots
ProjectDescr.Description:
Ralstonia solanacearum strain GMI1000. This strain is a race 1 strain isolated from the tomato plant and is also pathogenic on Arabidopsis thaliana. It specifically invades the plant xylem.

Pathogenicity factors include an extracellular polysaccharide that protects the bacterium and a type III secretion system (the hrp system) that is encoded on the megaplasmid and delivers effector molecules such as avirulence (Avr) proteins into the host cell. There is a type II secretion system for export of degradative enzymes such as plant cell wall hydrolases. This organism expresses a large number of outer membrane proteins including several that are related to hemagglutinins, as well as numerous fimbriae, including a type IV pilus for attachment and twitching motility. The two chromosomes contains many copies of insertion elements.

StructuredCitation.Title: Genome sequence of the plant pathogen Ralstonia solanacearum.

Author.Consortium: Genoscope and CNRS UMR-8030, 2 rue Gaston Cr√©mieux, CP5706, 91057 Evry Cedex, France.

ProjectDescr.Name: Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris str. 8004
ProjectDescr.Title: Causes black rot and citrus canker
ProjectDescr.Description: Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris strain 8004. This strain is a derivative of strain NCPBB No. 1145. The original was isolated from an inflected cauliflower in Sussex, United Kingdom, in 1958. Strain 8004 is a spontaneous rifampicin resistant strain and has been used extensively in many studies.

StructuredCitation.Title: Comparative and functional genomic analyses of the pathogenicity of phytopathogen Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris.

Author.Consortium: National Key Laboratory of Plant Genomics, Institute of Microbiology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080, PR China.

ProjectDescr.Name: Azotobacter vinelandii DJ strain:DJ
ProjectDescr.Title: Nitrogen-fixing bacterium
ProjectDescr.Description: Azotobacter vinelandii. This organism will provide information on the proteins involved in nitrogen fixation and the production of PHB and alginate.

StructuredCitation.Title: Genome sequence of Azotobacter vinelandii, an obligate aerobe specialized to support diverse anaerobic metabolic processes.
